Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

The teacher of the Shawanaga Day School has requested me to obtain, if possible, transportation for his pupils who are taking part in the Public School Field Day for the District. A preliminary field day was held at Shawanaga and there will be 17 entrants from that school in the main sports day which is to be held in Parry Sound. The only possible way that we could transport these children here would be by special bus which would cost $25.00 or $30.00. The field day will be held on June 11 and I will be obliged if you can advise me before that date if it would be possible for you to pass this expenditure.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
Mr. Samuel Devlin, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Parry Sound, Ont.

With reference to your letter of June 2nd, the Department will provide an amount not exceeding $30.00 for the pupils at the Shawanaga Day School to attend a public school field day for the district which is being held on June 11th.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

July 16, 1948.

Mr. S. Devlin, Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Parry Sound, Ontario.

Shawanaga Indian Day School.

We have now received Inspector Cassie's report of June 25 upon the above Indian Day School. He seems quite pleased with the work of the school on the whole and makes the following general comment:

"I wish to compliment the authorities for the improvements which have been made since my previous visit. Those noted were:

New trap-door on well.
Painting the interior of the school in approved colours.
Addition of more suitable reading material.
Addition of equipment and material for duplicating seat work exercises.
Removal of teacher's platform.

Suggested Improvements:

1. Removal of two sections of very shiny blackboard and erection of three sections of good slate board in their place. (This was suggested a year ago).

2. Addition of hardwood flooring where teacher's platform formerly was.

3. Immediate attention to toilet conditions. The boys' toilet is positively disgraceful. I am advised that most of the trouble is caused by community use of these facilities when dances are held nearby. In

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6163, file 428-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
In connection I recommend the installation of modified water toilets (not chemical) in a small anteroom which could be added to the south side of the school building.

"Mr. Morris continues to do very good work. The pupils' work is more nearly up to standard than a year ago. The improvement was most marked in oral reading but also quite noticeable in the written work. This continuity in Mr. Morris' tenure as teacher is having beneficial results."

With regard to his suggested improvements, would you please submit a requisition (if you have not already done so) for the blackboard required. It is now possible to get Nyleplaste board and we are endeavouring to replace all old blackboards with new ones.

In connection with the toilet conditions, would it be possible to put locks on the doors so that community use of these toilets can be stopped. We are making every effort to impress upon teachers and pupils of our schools that the cleanliness of school property and toilets is of great importance and that every effort must be made to avoid criticism such as has been made by Mr. Cassie.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Repairs to floors, windows and porch

Material $100.00
Labour 100.00

$200.00

(Sgd) Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.

Copied: V.S.
Parry Sound, Ont.,
August 6, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I am enclosing statement of repairs necessary for the various schools in this Agency.

The school on the Gibson Reserve had not been painted on the outside for a number of years and this job can now be done.

At the school at Shawanaga considerable damage had been done recently to the windows, as per my letter of July 20, and it will be necessary for me to send a glazier from Parry Sound to repair the damage. Hardwood flooring requires to be laid where the teacher's platform was taken out last year and the porch on the building needs considerable repair.

At the Lower French School the woodshed has collapsed and will require to be rebuild entirely. There is also some work to be done on the foundation of the school proper.

At the Ryerson School on Parry Island the kitchen drain has blocked up on various occasions with the result that the cellar has been flooded for lengthy periods. I believe that the drain will have to be dug up throughout its whole length and replaced.

If these expenditures are possible, I would be obliged if you would give me an accountable advance of $350.00 to pay for labour. Materials may all be purchased locally and the work will be done in all cases by Indian labour with the exception of the windows for the Shawanaga School.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Samuel Devlin
Indian Superintendent.

Copied: V.S.
Aug. 25, 1948.

Parry Sound, Ontario.

DATE: September 10, 1948
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Shawanaga Day School.

We have had considerable trouble in the last few years in obtaining water supply for the school and teacher's residence at Shawanaga. We have a well there about 16 feet deep but in very dry seasons, such as this year and last, the well dries up almost to the bottom. I have in mind driving a well point and fitting it with the necessary pipe and hand pump. I have not been able to get a price on the necessary equipment as yet and anticipate that there may be some difficulty in securing piping but would be glad to know if I may proceed with the project.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
September 29, 1948.

Mr. Samuel Devlin,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Parry Sound, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of
the 23rd instant regarding the well at the Shawanaga
Day School, you may follow out your plan, provided
the expenditure will not be excessive.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Educational Division.

Last winter we supplied soup for noon lunches at the Shawenaga Day School which appeared to work out very satisfactorily. I would be pleased to have your authority to purchase six cases of soup for this winter. I have obtained a price locally on this of $4.60 per case.

Yours truly,

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Educational Division.

On November 10 last I wrote you for permission to purchase 6 cases of soup to supply noon lunches at the Shawanaga Day School. Up to the present I have not received your authority to make this purchase and would be pleased to hear as soon as possible if I may do so.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
8th January, 1949.

Parry Sound, Ontario.

Sir,

I beg to inclose you herewith a letter received from Miss Jessie Campbell, the teacher at the Shawanaga Reserve, complaining that the bed in the teacher's house is in such a dilapidated condition that she is unable to sleep in it, requesting that a new one be purchased and sent to Shawanaga as soon as possible.

I understand, of course, that the council of the Band should make the request when any expenditure is granted out of their funds, but as it would take a considerable time to get them together to pass a resolution requesting your Department to sanction the purchase of a bed, and as it is quite evident that a new one is required at once, I beg to request you to authorize me to purchase one and send it to the Reserve as soon as possible.

I think the expenditure in purchasing a bed, sending it to Shawanaga, will not exceed $10.00.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Maclean

1905

Mr. W. B. McLean,
Parry Sound.

Dear Sir,

I am very sorry to have made such a mistake as I did in my last letter. Chief H. Jacobs came and asked me to write it and tried to tell me what he wanted me to say but I really cannot make out what he is saying. Since then his son has come back so through him I have found out what he meant. He was to get a team to draw the lumber for the woodshed for five dollars but couldn't get it done for less than four dollars so that is to be paid to the chief. Mr. John Mesheky did the work at the shed but he bought goods from Mr. Carpenter to amount to eight dollars and he was to get the money when Mesheky got it from you. So that is what is owing to Mr. Carpenter.

Hoping I have made it clear to you.

Yours Truly,
M. E. Tutt.

Sir,

I beg leave to inform you that I am in receipt of a letter from Miss Han, teacher of the Shawanaga Indian School, complaining of the snow drifting through the crevices in the gable ends of her cottage which makes it very uncomfortable. When she starts a fire in her stove, the snow melts and the drip falls through ceiling on her bedding and furniture. I promptly sent her some tar paper and advised Mr. Adam Parris to repair the defects at once. I acted on my responsibility for the comfort of the teacher and avoid any excuse of dissatisfaction.

I am Sir your obedient servant,

D'Allacourte

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 29th December 1907

I beg to explain how the teacher's house repairs commenced. Mr. Elias the teacher has planted a patch of potatoes and other vegetables. This autumn he dug a cellar at the end of the little house he resides in with the intention of building a lean-to the old house to increase the room for himself wife and two daughters. The eldest being a grown up young woman. The old house having but one room down stairs which serves as kitchen, sitting and dining room during the winter months.

One room upstairs for a bed-room (at one time this was ample room). When the teacher was one lone soul female. The Chief and the active members of the Band turned in and built the addition. And subsequently informed me what they have done. They were requested by me to carry resolution through the Council as to the payment for the material used.

There is no expense as far as the labor. I enclose you a snapshot photo of the teachers cottage before the present repairs and addition had been done. It is the poorest, coldest and smallest teachers dwelling in the country.

I am Sir your obedient servant

Your obedient servants,

Chief Henry Abetung
and Councillors.
Sir,

I beg to inform you that when I was at the Shawanagee Reserve, on the 29th of December, I found that the Teacher's house requires furnishing with cooking utensils and chairs. The cooking stove is in good order, the cooking utensils are nil excepting one pot. There are no table dishes. There is 3 broken chairs, and a badly wrecked rocker. There is a dining table and bedstead. The windows have passed through a siege, there are 16 panes of glass broken. The box stove was taken out of the house by Councilor Wesley Jacobs and put to use in his house. I inform the Chief that I would hold him responsible for the return of the stove in as good a condition as it was when taken out of the Teacher's house. It would appear that the late teacher and occupant of the house let things go to wreck and ruin when he learned that his services were required no longer. Please advise me what is to be done regarding the furnishing of the Teacher's house in this Agency as there will be more orders articles required at Parry Island as well.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Your obedient servant

INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE,

Sir,

In reply to your letter dated Aug. 23, I would say that I think as there are lots of gravel and sand right near school house, that a concrete foundation would be the cheapest and best. If the Department decide to put up a teacher house, the foundation could be done at the same time, so there is no hurry as long as it is done before the cold weather. I will submit a plan to you of an small house that might be suitable for teacher house and we could then get prices from some carpenters here and I will see an Indian named Adam Davis if he could do the work he lives at Shilo-awaga and is handy but you cannot depend on them very much. The Booth on hand the building of school bell tower but has not got finished yet.

I am your obedient servant,

Sir,

Specifications of material and labor required in the erection and completion of a teacher house on Shawanaga Reserve.

General Conditions:
The contractor to give his personal supervision to the work, to furnish all necessary materials and labor for the proper carrying on of the work to its entire completion—whether specified or not—all materials to be of good quality, sound and firm.

All work to be finished in a plain and substantial way as directed and all to be given up at completion in a complete and undamaged state without exception. All to be done to the entire satisfaction of the Indian Superintendent or other official appointed by the Department of Indian Affairs.

Basement:
Excavate to the depth, size, and form shown on foundation plan. Excavate 6 inches wider on each side than walls to allow for footings. Level ground around building after completion to a proper grade to allow drainage from building.

Foundation walls and piers:
To be 18" thick, of plain rubble masonry or good concrete work 12" thick nicely smoothed and pointed up on the outside, above ground.

Plate for Foundation:
Properly level and bed in good mortar. A 2x6 plate on stone wall and piers to carry joisting. Stone work to be beamfilled on outside to top of joists.

Chimney:
Build chimney with 9x9 flue on bucket where shown on plan with proper collars etc. complete, to be built of good cement bricks in good lime mortar.

Ground Floor Joists etc.:
Carpentering and joiner work. Joists to be 2x8 hemlock 16" centers, will be nailed to plates and studs with 4" spikes. Bridge joists between, with 2x2 herring-bone bridging nailed with 3" nails to joists.

Ceiling Joists.
Sir,

Ceiling Joists.
To be 2x6 on 16" centers well nailed.

Studding.
To be 2x4 hemlock doubled at corners and at all openings at 16" centers. The plate to be 2x4 doubled in long lengths and well nailed together all interior partitions to be 2x3, set at 16" centers and have bottom and top plates.

Rafters.
To be 2x6 at 18" centers properly framed at heel and spiked to plates.

Rough sheeting.
Cover all walls and roof laid close, with good quality hemlock sheeting well nailed to studs and rafters. Cover all outside walls and roof with two thicknesses of good tarred roofing paper, to be tacked and secured to boarding before siding is put on.

Siding.
To be a good quality of narrow pine siding well nailed with 2½ and a half nails.

Roof.
Cover entire roof with best quality of xxx cedar shingles laid four and a half inches to the weather and well nailed with shingle nails.

Door and window Frames.
All door and window frames to be made of good quality pine also sash and doors to be well made of best pine.

Flooring.
Floors joists to be covered with good quality hemlock lumber laid close, dressed on one side, and well nailed and covered with one thickness of tarred paper and flopped over with tongues and groved pine flooring, blind nailed at each joist. Finish all interior with good quality pine casings, and base boards casing with neat Architectural moulding running all around.
Sir,

Chair Strip:
Put a neat 4" chair strip all round dining and sitting rooms and wainscoting round kitchen 3ft. high with matched and beaded narrow lumber, and a neat cap on top.

Hardware:
Fit all doors with good Mortise locks and loose pin steel butts. Exterior doors to have strong locks and two keys. Build outside steps to exterior doors well built of pine lumber with 2" strings and 2 risers housed into strings and put together as per elevations.

Lathing and Plastering:
Lath all walls, ceiling, partitions, etc., with first quality pine laths well nailed to studs, joints broken every 18".

Brown Coat:
Then give all portions lathed one good coat of brown hair mortar, composed of fresh burned lime and clean sharp sand. Mortar to be made up long enough to be well soured, to make a good lasting job. All angles to be made plumb straight and true, surfaces level.

Finishing Coat:
When first coat is dry, cover all with a good putty coat well gauged and trowelled to a hard even surface.

Painting and Glazing:
Painting—Paint all the exposed wood work of exterior and interior usually painted with two coats of lead and oil paint tinted as directed. Lead to be the best Canadian White Lead and pure boiled Canadian linseed oil free from all adulterant. All wood work to be carefully knotted with shellac and alcohol and stopped with pure white lead putty after priming and carefully rubbed down with sandpaper.

Glazing:
The whole of the windows to be glazed with best quality common clean glass free from bubbles and weds. To be properly primed before glazing ad glass to be sprigged bedded and putted.
May 14, 1913.

Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
New dwelling house for the Teacher of the Sh...aga Indian Day School.

The Indian Superintendent of Parry Sound reports to the effect that it would be better in the long run to build a new house than to continue repairing the present one which he says is an old shack unfit for a home.

Money is available from the Vote for Indian Education.

The Department's advertisements called for the submission of an accepted cheque for ten per cent of the amount of the tender in each case. Mr. Riddell, the lowest tenderer did not submit a security cheque as did the other two tenderers. As Mr. Riddell is reported by the Indian Superintendent as being a reliable man, the Department telegraphed the Superintendent that if Mr. Riddell would submit a security cheque his tender would be considered, but the Superintendent wired in reply that Mr. Riddell refused to submit a cheque and consequently the Department does not consider that his tender should be entertained, it is therefore proposed to accept the next tender, that of Mr. Kaufman.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

Frame Teacher's Residence,

Shawanaga Reserve

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the Thirtieth day of September A.D. 1913.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of One Thousand and twenty seven dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

Sir;

Replying to yours of Oct. 6th, 22-5-8, re repairs to the teacher's house at Shawanaga, I have to state that I have examined this house and there is no doubt that it requires to be plastered, the walls fixed up with murocco, and the woodwork painted. The railing of the verandah needs to be fixed up.

I understand they are doing some plastering at the church, and I have suggested to Mrs. English, the school teacher, that when they are doing that, she could get them to fix up her place in the meantime, as a neighbourly turn, and we could wait and have the repairs done after the estimates are in, in March.

I have explained to Mrs. English that as teachers go she has not much complaint; as she is fairly comfortable, and she admits that this is so, but I would recommend that provision be made for repairs for this house in the estimates in March. This might amount to somewhere between $25.00 and $30.00, you can never just say how much it would cost, when patching plastering, but my intentions are whatever is absolutely necessary in the plastering line can be done now without any cost to the Department.

Should the Department approve of these repairs being done during the coming summer holidays, I think the possibilities are that they
could be done much cheaper than at the present time.

at their earliest if I can get this sheet metal heater

Sir,

In reply to your memorandum of the 17th instant I beg to say that the Pays Plat Reserve is situated on a river of that name, about eight miles west of Rosport, which is the nearest post office and railway station. The Reserve runs down to the C.P.R. line and passengers can alight at the Tankhouse which is about a quarter of a mile from the school. The teacher would have a free dwelling separate from the school.

Extract from a letter dated Fort William Ont., 26th Oct 1897

At Pays Plat, Miss Nora Murphy, the teacher, informed me a few days ago that on the 1st of next month, she will give up her school, remarking however, that her quarter ending only December 31st she having taken but few of the holidays to which she was entitled under the regulations of the Department, no other teacher could be nominated to the vacant position before that date.

Now dear sir, while I am far from begrudging the good young lady who has been so painstaking in the fulfilment of her duty, any salary she has a right to, or that the Department may see fit to grant her, I am most anxious to have the vacancy filled up as soon as possible.

Of course Miss Murphy has made up her mind to give up the school on other grounds too, but none the less, she told me that she should not have kept it anyhow, as the building would be too cold in winter for her.

This is perfectly true, dear sir, and I beg to add, in this connection that both at Pays plat and at Pic River, we shall always have hard work as we have had already to retain our lady teachers, may even to get any at all, as long as the school buildings are what they are at present, simply unfit to be inhabited by any of them during our severe winters.

I am sorry to have to say so but it is the truth.

Moreover I am of opinion that with what has been spent on them in repairs, new cones could almost have been built, thus giving teachers at least a net and warm place to live in. The houses are too far gone.

By November 1st we shall have 2 vacancies in this District, one at Pic River and the other at Pays Plat. One of the two I expect to fill shortly, as I have for sometime been in correspondence with a new teacher for the former place. The Candidate is a young lady. I may say that our men teachers have given less satisfaction than the ladies.

I am dear sir, &c.,

Revd Jos Specht S.J., Missionary.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Sup't. General.

Agent Bonin was asked to consult with the Superintendent of Missions at Fort William with a view to obtaining a teacher for the Pays Plat School. He reports that the Rev. Father Bugaswith is of opinion that it would be useless to try and get a teacher unless the building were put into better shape. He suggests that the Department might spend the amount voted for salary in putting up a school building and after that a teacher might be secured. I think it very doubtful whether any competent white teacher would remain any length of time at Pays Plat and I would not recommend spending anything on the building at present. It would be better to make provision for the number of children on the reserve that could attend school either at Wikwemikong or the Fort William Orphanage than to go to the expense of putting up a new building and paying the teacher's salary.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Paget of this Department, who visited the Fort William Agency this fall, recommends that the Pays Plat School be re-opened.

This school has been closed since 1901 and on several occasions since then its re-opening has been suggested. There are several reasons why this has not been done, one is the difficulty of securing a teacher to go there, another is that there is no suitable accommodation in the way of a school or teacher's residence and a third reason is the question of attendance. There are only 39 Indians in the band as shown by the census and 9 children of school age. Mr. Paget informs me that some of the younger children are now old enough to go to school, but the number would not exceed 10 or 12 at the most, and it is doubtful whether the attendance would justify the maintenance of a school there. The school has been dropped from the estimates for a number of years and provision would have to be made for carrying it on.

REPORT

Re:- General conditions amongst the Indians -
Pays Plat Indian Reserve.

First report:

A complaint was received from Chief Louis Mushquash and Joe Fisher - Indian Constable of the Pays Plat Indian Reserve in regards to the condition of the schoolhouse after being put in use as a boarding house for the Robert and Heron Bay Indians while under employment on the Trans Canada Highway near Pays Plat.

On my arrival at the Indian Reserve, I inspected the said schoolhouse, found same empty and in a dirty and filthy condition. Seven panes of glass were found broken, one door and partition broken, and some of it had been used as kindling.

A water pail had been lent them which was first used for boiling beans, and afterwards as a toilet which was left in the house. Old clothing left on the floor is covered with lice, and the twelve Indians who have resided inside have been using any place outside around the building as a place for garbage and toilet.

I consider that it will cost approximately $25.00 to fix this Government building, known as the schoolhouse at Pays Plat Indian Reserve.

A further complaint was made by Chief Louis Mushquash to the effect that on the arrival of the Indians from Robert and Heron Bay Indian Reserves to work on the Trans Canada Highway, he boarded 12 Indians from the 8th January to 26th January, keeping track of each individual meal. He made a charge of .50¢ per meal, and adds up to a bill of $30.20. Up to the present time he has not received a cent from any one of these Indians, and they have now gone back to their Indian Reserves.

Before leaving the Pays Plat Indian Reserve, one of the Robert Indians Joe Bananash gave a note to Chief Louis Mushquash for $2.00, and another note to Henry Mushquash for $3.00 which they produced and showed to me, and up to the present time this money has not been paid back to them.

Several of the Pays Plat Indians complained that although they had been laid off work from the Trans Canada Highway for nearly a month, that they had not received their last pay cheques from the Northern Development of Ontario, and that they did not owe a cent to anyone. The names of Indians with cheques due are as follows:-

Thomas Wesley - Approx. $35.00 Lawrence Mushquash - Approx. $1
Fred Auger - $40.00 Steve Auger - $2.6
Henry Mushquash - $30.00

On visiting at the various Indian homes, I find that a few old people are destitute, especially Tom Waboose age 75 years, lives by himself, and has resorted to the practice of begging around Indian homes for his meals.

Sarah McKenzie - age 60 years, paralyzed in right arm, living by herself, makes a strong request for some wood to be furnished her as well as some rations and clothing. She is having trouble with her teeth, and cannot eat any meat.

Dear Sir,

I visited the school at Bay Plat today; everything is in pretty good order. Two classes are starting at the school, and we in the little house where the teacher used to stay. I will lend her my room in the church, but that little house is repaired. Besides the windows, the roof wants to be repaired also. I was glad that Miss Clark will find the place to love. Some to stay I would prefer to see Miss Alice Barker take that school, she already taught there, and his willing to take the school again if the Department agrees to take her again. She always gave satisfaction at Bay Plat and West Bay where she was teaching last year. It seems to me that it would be preferable to give the Bay Plat school to Miss Barker because she knows the place, and also believe she would be able to board herself with her mother who would stay with her here. The Indians asked me to try to have Miss Barker.

Your obedient servant,

W.R. Brown

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter "151866/5" of the 1st instant re Pay's Flat School.

Chief Friday will rent his house at $25 per month. This is in the centre of the village and is larger and much more suitable in every way than the present building which is across the river from the village.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to Mr. Agent Brown's letter of the 19th instant applying for a grant of $500.00 to purchase the building at present used for school purposes on the Pays Plat Reserve I beg to say that the Department is paying a rental of $60.00 a year for this building. This school was only re-opened last January, having been closed fourteen years ago for want of a suitable building in which to hold school. If it is to be continued the Department should have a building of its own. A new building could not be put up for less than $1500.00 and if the present one with slight repairs could be made suitable I think it would be to the Department's interest to purchase it. Mr. Brown says that $100.00 would put it in good shape.

The school is in charge of a Mrs. McLaren, who seems to be satisfied with her surroundings, and the enrolment for the last quarter was 23, with an average attendance of 18.

To Indian Department

Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am regarding about the school house here at Pays Platt Band. I was talking to Mr. Paget last summer here about that school house that I was think to buy that school house sometime. So Mr. Paget told me when he get down to Ottawa he will let me know how much it will be worth, so I never had no word yet. So I will like to hear from you this summer about that school house and this school house it long time since the school was close here, and this
House is in bad shape now last summer that house it was all wet inside, roofing was leaking bad. And last fall I went to work, fix up the roofing; in good part.

I remain yours Truly

Chief Louis Mushywash

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, stating that you desire to purchase the Pays Plat Indian day school building.

Ottawa, July 8th, 1924.

Sir:

The Department has received a request from Chief Louie Mushquash, of the Pays Plat Band, stating that he is desirous of purchasing the building formerly used for school purposes on that Reserve. This school has been closed for a number of years, and the Chief states that the building is falling into disrepair.

Please inform the Department as to whether you consider that this building would be of any further use for school purposes and whether you consider it would be necessary at a future date to re-open the school. If you would recommend that the building be sold, please state the sum which you consider would be a fair estimate of the value of the building. Your early reply giving the information asked for will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Bulk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Sir -

Re No. 9-6-5

Replying to your letter of the 8th ultimo, I beg to say that Chief Mushquash is living in this building and is paying no rent and I consider that he should keep it in repair if he continues to live there without paying any rental. It is doubtful if he would even pay for it if the Department did sell it to him.

Several years ago the Department purchased this building from an Indian for school purposes and the records at Ottawa will show what was paid for it. It is unlikely that it will ever be required again for school purposes but I would not recommend selling it to Chief Mushquash unless he can show how he could pay for it within a reasonable time.

The Chief should have made his request to the Department through the Indian Agent and the practice of Indians writing direct to the Department should be discouraged as it impairs the usefulness of the Agent and leads the Indians to ignore him.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. BURK
INDIAN AGENT

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 12th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to the request made by Chief Louie Mushquash, of the Pays Plat Band, to live in the building formerly used for school purposes.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will have no objection to his occupying this building, provided he will agree to be responsible for any repairs that may be required. The Department cannot consent to the sale of the building, but, until such time as it is required, Chief Mushquash may occupy it as a residence without rental. You will be good enough to inform him that it is expected he will keep the building in a satisfactory state of repair.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Sir,

The school teachers dwelling house at Poy's Plat Reserve is in a bad condition, so much so that the teacher who came there last month says she cannot live in it without some repairs to make it habitable, and asked to be moved to the Pie, where the school house is ready to live in, to which request the Reverend Missionary Priest Father Nadeau and myself consented, and another teacher engaged for the 1st of next month, will take Poy's Plat Reserve school, and by that time with the Department's permission I will have the necessary improvements or repairs done, and are as follows:

The back addition of logs a lean-to, is covered with poles and leaks so badly that it cannot be used for wood or any other purpose and can be covered with bark for $1.50, the water closet that was there, Miss and Miss Barker the last teacher took it, packed boxes to move away, also some of the inside lining boards; another water closet can be built inside this wood shed 3 x 4 feet - with 250 feet of lumber at $15 = $3.75 building it and digging hole & boxing hole 3.25 10 Rolls of wall paper, which the teacher

Deputy Sect. General
Of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
and Indians can put on the wall and cheaper than white washing 10 Rolls $450 1.25, taking down the stairs, which takes up too much room, and boarding up the hole 6 x 5 feet, to keep heat from all ascending up aloft $1.25, and putting a partition across the centre making two Rooms a Kitchen and bed room 15 x 8 feet 200 feet lumber $3.00 lumber - making the partition and door and nails $2.70 and an 18 inch Box stone for Bed Room as the old cooking stove does not give heat enough to warm the house $4.50, and as the stone pipe now there is too old and dangerous will require 12 bricks at 15 cents $1.80 - except $2.00 total amount $23.75.

I am Sir
Your obedient Servt.,
J. D. Dunnelly

Dear Sir,

With reference to the school teacher lately appointed for Shikshigwaning, kindly forward to the Department of Indian Affairs the following considerations.

The Indian Act, section 76 (a) says that chiefs may frame regulations as to what religious denomination the teacher of the school established on the reserve shall belong to; but because the legislators foresaw the case that a chief might be influenced by parties against the religious persuasion of the majority and the best advantage of all, they added the following restriction: "Provided that always he (the teacher) shall be of the same denomination as the majority of the band." It showing that they admitted no exception to that point.

Now at Shikshigwaning, according to the census taken a little more than two weeks ago by Rev. Father Specht, there are 145 Roman Catholics, and 5 Protestants. Consequently, it was not in the power of the chief to ask for a Protestant teacher, and it was the duty of those who are the guardians of the law to refuse him: "The teacher, says the Act, shall be always of the same denomination as the majority of the band."

But I am told that it is upon the request of the band that the appointment in question has been made. So this Summer that his request being evidently against the provisions of the law, was not to be considered. Suppose that a band would send a request to the effect of appointing to the office of Indian Agent a man who is not a British subject; what answer would be given to that request?

Rev. Father found that the men of age, that is, being 21 years old, were in all 54 at Nishigamang, and although many were then absent, sixteen only remaining. Seven (7) of them declared positively that they never wanted to have a protestant teacher, while five (5) only agreed that they did so. Among the eleven are one of the councillors and an ex-chief; and two widows' heads of families are to be added to them. Among the five one is now sorry for what he did.

Here are now the very words of a few, whose names I have here: "I signed my name to ask for a teacher, but I didn't, and the Indians did not ask for a Protestant teacher." The one who said so is a councillor; another, an ex-chief: "We only asked the Department for another teacher; but we did not say that we wanted him to be a Protestant." Another: "To say that the band asked for a Protestant teacher, is to say altogether a falsehood. Only three men spoke in favor of a Protestant. They told the Department a lie. Those who pretended that these three men represented the Band."

The newly appointed teacher is an intelligent man; he knows the laws, and wonders himself how he can be teaching in a village nearly all Catholic, because, as he said to the Indians "That is never done". As a matter of fact, no body has ever heard of a Catholic being appointed to teach in a Protestant reserve.

Rev. Father Specht inquired also into the cause that brought about that difficulty. It appears to be that the Division did not...
chance enough in their studies, and that the fathers did not send better teachers.

But whose fault is it chiefly, that the children did not progress more, if not of the parents who never sent regularly their boys or girls to school, and did not see that they would talk or read any English at home? Besides it may be said that the principal reason of the failure of the school at Pishigwining, as I remember, and the cause why we could not find better teachers, is the quasi-impossibility to get any really competent person willing to remain in the country with no society, no comfortable lodging, a very poor boarding, not the least distraction, to earn only $200 or $250 dollars less the necessary expenses.

It ought to be said here also that the last teacher has not been sent by my predecessor, but after receiving a petition made in his favor by some of the principal men, and after telling them that the man was hardly fit for the situation.

On finishing this letter, founded upon the text of a letter perfectly clear, I pray the Department of Indian Affairs to discharge Mr. John Lagimaw at the beginning of the next quarter,...to increase the salary of the teacher and to inform me on time of the vacancy of the school, so that, according to the privilege granted to the Superior of those Missions I may propose the appointment of some reliable person.

Although we are grateful to the Department for the privilege in question, and take it as a proof of its good dispositions towards us, we also know that it is one the employment of which causes us a great deal of difficulties with very little satisfaction. And it will be so as long as we cannot offer better wages and better conditions of lodging and boarding. We think also that were we to renounce that privilege the Department would be...
very often in the impossibility of doing any better; and having more Protestant teachers disposed than Catholic ones, they will more than once neglect to observe the Section 76 (a) of the law. OTTAWA, 12th September, 1900.

The Secretary:

Mr Agent Thorburn encloses a letter from Miss O'Rielly, the newly appointed teacher for the Sheshegwaning school, in which she states that at the time of her engagement Rev. Father Artus informed her that her salary would be $225.00 a year.

The teacher's salary of this school is paid by the Band and up to the present time $200.00 is all that has been given. Miss O'Rielly says that she cannot stay unless she is paid at least $250.00 and the Agent states that a qualified teacher cannot be got to take the school for less. Sheshegwaning is an isolated place where the common necessaries of life are expensive and I think that $250.00 is little enough to offer any white person to undertake the work there.

Of the sixteen schools on Manitoulin Island and the North Shore between Garden River and the Parry Sound Agency, eight are in receipt of a salary of only $200.00 a year, while the others are paid from $250.00 to $300.00. The schools for which the smaller salaries are provided have been under the charge of Indian or half-breed teachers and have made little or no progress, they having no experience or qualifications, and Separate School Inspectors White and Prendergast will bear out this statement.
I think that where a qualified white teacher can be obtained for a school in this locality that $300.00 is little enough, and where one is willing to take $250.00, the Department should not hesitate to pay it.

The Agent further states that the Indians of Sheshgwaning are anxious to have their children properly educated and I think that the Band might be taxed with the additional $50.00 to make up the salary of $250.00 which the Agent recommends should be paid Miss O'Rielly, as if she gives up the school at the end of this quarter, they will be left without a teacher for the rest of the winter at least.

under their charge and doubtless their untired services have been the benefit of both children and adults. The great influence of these ladies on the adult population was of the most encouraging features to be noted.

But to enable this good work to go on the Department must provide residences for these ladies that will be habitable during winter without serious injury to health. This applies with special force to Capilano and Skeetchewaning. Unless the residence in the first named place is put into proper repair the teachers would be forced to risk their lives to remain there during winter; and that is the time when they will find most of the business at the village. At Skeetchewaning the teachers will take charge at the opening of next term if some respectable accommodations can be provided. in part through the unfriendliness of the band to having school at all. I have strong hopes that the district will effect a great improvement here if arrangements can be made to place them in charge.

Dear Sir,—Your liberal favor of the 28th ult. received last Saturday. As mail leaves here only once a week; this is my first opportunity to acknowledge it and to express my sincere thanks to the Department for their kindness in increasing my salary to four hundred dollars. I shall try to show my gratitude by continuing as faithfully as I can, to serve them in the persons of these Indians.

I must confess that last summer, and still more this past winter, I was very seriously tempted to leave this place, not only on account of the difficulty and expense to reach it, but also because of the carelessness of parents in sending their children to school. But I cannot leave now when the Department has shown such appreciation of my efforts. I am inclined to think the Department appreciates it more than many of the Indians.

If you will allow me to suggest, I would say that now is an opportune time to require attendance at school. I told the Chief and his assistant what I wrote in my report last February, and they expect...
that something will be done. The Chief Joseph Sampson very anxiously inquired a couple of weeks ago if the Dept. had written me anything about those who do not attend school. I answered that it is not likely the that the Dept. would write to me about it, all they want to know from me is if school is well attended. A few words of advice from the Dept. would perhaps have good effect just now. I told the chief that no doubt I would have a similar report to write next year, to show if there has been any improvement.

I wish to thank the Department also for the promised assistance in supplying materials. In my next report, I will mention what I think is fair. I am most willing and anxious to interest the women in the work of cooking especially; all can sew fairly well. We have incessantly worked to teach them how to care for their sick and give them proper food.

I fear I cannot do much this spring in looking after the women, as I am just recovering from a severe attack of lumbago which kept me out of school two weeks, but I will do what I can and try to have at least one or two meetings before the summer holidays.

Dear Sir:—A request made by the Department, in your letter of July 14th, 1911, No. 157713/1, as to the annoyance caused me by the chief, has remained unanswered, not through carelessness, but through the repugnance I felt in making known what I thought I could bear. However, I think it my duty to tell you his conduct of late.

Early last fall, several men asked me to give them the contract for the cutting of the wood for the school and house. I had about given it to one, when the chief came and told me not to give it to anyone, that he would see to it. I then gave him in writing, the number of cords needed with
the kind of wood, which was 26 cords of maple and 3 cords of cedar; all 2 ft. wood.

The first few cords were all maple, then I noticed birch mixed in. I told the man who was hauling it, that I did not mind having a little birch in the school wood, as there is no chimney on the school, only a straight stone pipe, but for the house, I wanted only maple as birch fills the chimney and pipes, and some years ago, when we had accepted a good deal of birch, we had several fires. He told the chief, so the first few cords of the house wood were a mixture of maple and oak. But soon saw that there was birch, so I again spoke to the man. Then we had a thaw and no more wood could be brought.

The chief came to say that the wood was all cut and asked for the account to send the Department. I told him that he had not kept his agreement to send maple and cedar; I added that I would keep the little birch that was already here, if he would take for himself or someone else the birch that was in the bush and bring maple instead. He promised to do so, and said the three cords of cedar were cut.
I knew and felt I was doing wrong in giving him the account with my signature, and I told him so; but he said, as they all do:

"It takes so long to get money from the Department, and there was no knowing when there would be snow, and that he would surely bring it down when there would be snow. I let myself be persuaded and gave him the paper. Two weeks ago, he began to draw the wood; the first was three cords of tamarack instead of cedar. When he brought the first load, I told him I did not want that. He said it was better than cedar for kindling.

I inquired from other men, all said that tamarack is not kindling wood, that it cracks stones and easily sets fire to chimneys. The next day I asked him please not to unload that wood. He at once became very angry and said many things to me, one was that he would put the wood there and if I would not use it he would lock the school and send me away. I told him no, I would not go, and as this wood would be used only next winter, I did not think the Dept.
approve my accepting it as it would destroy
the furnace they are putting in the new
school, and that I could not, in conscience,
do so. He, however, unloaded the three cords
then went to nearly all the men in their
homes, told them I was not satisfied
with the wood and said that if I told
the agent on him he would send me
away at once; but for that, he wants
them to help him by signing a petition to
that effect. I telephoned the agent to ask him
to keep the cheque when it would come from
the Department, until all was made right.
he said he would come the following
week, but no doubt the weather prevented
him from coming.

This week, the chief brought the
rest of what he calls the hard wood,
a mixture of maple, elm, birch, and
tamarack. It is useless to argue with
him so I said nothing. I spoke to the
Assistant chief, he said he has been looking
for this trouble as he knew what wood
was out in the bush. he could answer
nothing when I asked him why he did
not tell me before.
The chief who, when he was in office some years ago, annoyed the Department, I am told, by requesting several times to have a public school, is still trying to persuade the people to renew the attempt. He does not approve of Domestic Science work, gardening, calisthenics, etc., all that is a loss of time he thinks, and judges of the knowledge of the children by his own who are seldom in school. He takes good care though, not to inquire how much those know, who attend regularly. Some young men are quite put out because the chief says they can read and write very little, they say he has never asked them to read anything for him; one is our post master, Noel Dominic, another, his half brother Daniel Sampson, two smart, good and honest young men, of whom he should be proud.

The chief may not be able to do much, still he may get a few ignorant and timid ones, not willing to contradict him.

I certainly do not mind him, but do my duty quietly and conscientiously, it is
not pleasant to have him constantly find fault and trying to influence others. The children, too, hear that language, and consequently, do not care to study since the chief says the school is no good. One woman told him last week, that he would do far better to talk less and see that the children go to school, and not allow the girls to be kept home for a trifle and the boys of 12 yrs. of age to work. Many are dissatisfied with him, even those who voted for him.

I am here nearly ten years and was never annoyed by the chiefs, but since this one is in office, not one year yet, I hear nothing but fault finding, not only with me but with everyone who tries to do right.

I do not know what the agent will do in regard to the wood when he comes, but I thought it well to acknowledge myself my mistake in giving the account of the wood before it was here, and to tell you some of the things I have to bear from the chief.

Most sincerely yours,

Adèle Ducharme

MEMORANDUM -

Mr. Scott -

GORE BAY AGENCY continued,

SHESEGWANING.

As I had to catch the mail boat on Monday morning, I found it necessary to visit Shesegwaning on the 27th ultimo. I met the teachers of both the Protestant and Roman Catholic schools and several of the more prominent Indians.

With reference to the Protestant school, a new building should be erected. Mr. Dunn, the present teacher, is leaving, and His Grace Archbishop Thernsloe has made arrangements for a married man to take up the work here. He holds a professional certificate, and I do not know where they are going to find accommodation for him. They have erected a very neat chapel, and as the work of the Anglican Church here would appear to be permanent, so far as can be judged.
at present, it would seem advisable to erect a combined school and residence. They have a small garden plot in connection with this school, but they were late in commencing, and the results have not been very good this year.

I also visited the Roman Catholic school and met Miss Leusch, the teacher. This is a splendid institution and was, if you will recollect, erected for the purpose of accommodating all the children of the village and district, who were then Roman Catholics. Miss Leusch has a splendid garden, and is doing excellent work. She has trained a band of fifteen pieces. She drew my attention to several minor repairs which I would propose to take up with the Schools' Branch and have attended to. Both these schools are really too small to do the best work, but the situation is such that no other course was open to the Department but to establish the second school.

The Indians on this reserve are showing an interest in agriculture, and although I did not have time to cover the whole of the reserve there is some very fair agricultural land. This is another reserve where a survey should be made
at some time in the near future, although I do not consider it so imperative as the Wikwemikong survey.

Dear Mr. MacKenzie,-

What pleased me most about the Silver Water Fair was that it was the children of the families that remain at home all summer that took the first and second prizes. I pointed out the fact to both parents and children.

Since then I have done a great deal of planning and thinking, wondering what could be done to encourage more, or better still, all our men to remain on their farms instead of wasting their time and money on the North Shore, waiting a week or more for a boat to come and then spending the few dollars as fast as they are earned.

Several returned yesterday with no money, nor an idea of what they will do if there is no work the coming winter. I am questioning every one as they return and trying to make them see the foolishness of working this way. Would encouragement from the Department be a help to them?
Among other things I thought that if the Dept. would find it advisable to give them perhaps $5.00 for every new acre they clear and cultivate the coming year it might spur them on a little. Then next fall have a fair in the village for the grown people, giving prizes for best crops and best yield per acre.

Of course, I have no experience in this kind of work and have not had an opportunity to talk it over with anyone, though I mentioned it to Rev. Fr. Papineau at his last visit. I am sorry I did not meet Mr. Abrahams, he would likely have had some good suggestions. Perhaps the Department has tried plans in other reserves and will know what is best to do.

I am only trying all I can to help these people and make them better and I have found in every place that I have taught that those remaining on the farms are far better than the others.

Very respectfully yours,

Elizabeth Leusch.

Dear Sir,

For the past few days we are having a great deal of trouble and ill feeling here. A number of the Anglicans are constantly coaxing the Catholics to join them. Seeing that they cannot succeed in this, they are now trying to persuade them to send their children to their school telling them that they would learn so much more there and that they could remain Catholic while doing so.

I have worked for the Department for the past sixteen years and believe that I have always given satisfaction, at least, I have been told so repeatedly by inspectors and others.

Of course, there are always a few who are bound to find fault here.
John Simon is the worst of these. Every now and then I have trouble with him because he does not wish his children to do garden work, manual training, fall fair work etc. His idea of school is to sit in the class room, book in hand from 9 A.M. until 4 P.M.

He is now taking his children away from here to place them in the Anglican school. William Cook who has been coaxed for a long time took his yesterday, so I have lost 6 pupils.

Our Indians told me that they were told, by a representative from the Department, at the time when it was decided to open the second school that the children of each religion were to go to their own school.

I should be most grateful to know if a regulation of this kind exists or could possibly be made in case it does not exist.
A decision of this kind would put an end to the trouble. As it is now there is a great deal of quarreling and bad feeling.

Our Inspector Mr. Evans was here only this week and expressed himself as well pleased so I do not think that there is any foundation for the Anglican's assurance that the children would learn more there.

I would also be grateful to know if the school is Anglican or Public. He always understood it to be Anglican but those who are doing the coaxing claim it to be a public school.

Assuring you of my gratitude for a favourable reply, I remain,

Most respectfully yours,

Elizabeth Lewis,
Teacher

About a month ago part of the lumber and building paper came, but no windows, hinges, poultry netting etc.

The grates of the furnaces have been burned out since last winter. I have repeatedly asked for new ones but have not received them.

The pump of the cistern has been out of order for nearly two months. Mr. Baxter said that a part was worn out and promised to have it repaired at once, but we are still waiting.

I would be most grateful if the Department could arrange matters so we would not be obliged to wait so long for everything needed.

It is hard enough to live all year forty miles from civilization—I might say, without being put to unnecessary trouble through neglect of an Indian Agent.

Thanking you in advance, I remain

Most respectfully yours,

Dear Sir,-

Just a few lines to you. I received one letter from teacher, Elizabeth Leuch, from Sheshegwaning Reserve, she call me down just because I want my children to go to Public School at Sheshegwaning. I tell you I am willing to send my children to Public School at Sheshegwaning. I had been give to D. E. Sampson permission to put my children to Public School at Sheshegwaning Indian Reserve. I understand some of the Indians get excited just because I want another school. Will you please tell Miss E. Leuch, the school teacher at Sheshegwaning, not to bother my children, and tell the other Indians not to get excited about my family. I tell you some of the Indians at Sheshegwaning alway trying to make my wife sore. I don't want any them Indians to bother my family. D. E. Sampson is the man to look after my family till I come back home. I want to tell you another thing, the priest might try to take my children to Spanish School, I don't want him to do that, will you please look after this matter, and when you see my wife tell her to mind her own business, not to listen to what the R.C. Indians say to her. I tell you my wife been worrying about me. I think she had enough trouble now. I don't want any of them Indians to bother my wife, I am the man looking after my wife, I am sure she is doing what I told her to do.

Just a few words again just to let you know how I am getting along. I feel very healthy, this country we have very good meals every day, and lots of smokes, I am living first class. This is the best job I struck yet on this
world, I wish all my young friends come along and follow me. I have lots of fun here with the Huns. Every time I hear them Bang, Bang, Zip, Zip, I feel happy, its sound like Banjo. This is a very noisy place. I chew the tob. Here now to beat the Band, every time the big shell burst around me I take another chew and I spit about every one minute. I tell you this is lots of fun for me. I wish some more good mens come along and help us to win the war.

I left five children and my wife at home, in Canada, to fight for my loving country and my loving family and today I been doing my duty; for two months in France, and I will stick to it till the war is over. Close my letter now.

Yours truly,

Pte. William Cook, from Sheshegwaning Reserve.

Dear Sir,

As some of the Indians are dissatisfied and may ask for a change of teachers I thought best to inform you of the true cause of the trouble.

A few weeks after I sent in my yearly report stating that a great deal of drinking was going on in the village. Mr. McReynolds came and told the Indians that someone had reported them to the Government and that he would send a constable to watch them. The Indians at once suspected that I was the one who had informed the Government. To make things worse, the constable from Isle Bay came about two weeks later, early in the evening, in his uniform, and drove straight to the school. Of course they soon thought he came to get more information from me.
All this has excited some of the Indians very much.

In the first place, I think Mr. McGregor ought to have been more prudent than to tell the Indians that some one had reported them and that they were going to be watched. He might have known that they would be on the lookout for the constable and keep straight while they are afraid of being caught.

The Indians will get over their ill feeling in a short time because they know it does not bother me. But I thought it best to let you know where the trouble is so in case they do write, you could give them the answer they should have.

Respectfully yours,

Elizabeth Sweet

Dear Mr. Bennett,

I thought I would write to you telling you I'm attending school every day and I enjoyed your visit very much. We are learning a lot this year. I'm in Jr. Third. All of us are speaking the English Language at recreation time especially at noon. There are only eighteen children.

Every night we come to the May Devotions.

I remember what you said about going to Mass and communion every time when Rev. Father Papineau comes. I'm saying my prayers every night and every morning.

I guess I'll stop.

Dear Mr. Bennett,

As this is our composition time I decided to write a little letter to you. I was glad I could see you when you came here to our Reserve. I expect you to come again next spring.

I suppose you would like to know about our gardens. We have just started it two days ago. We planted five or six pails of potatoes yesterday. On Friday we are going to plant again. After awhile we will plant carrots, beets, onions, corn, pumpkins and tomatoes.

The Department is not prepared to authorize any expenditure in excess of $75 in having dental work performed on this Reserve. You should arrange to have the Dentist visit the Reserve at a time considered convenient by the teachers and yourself to have the work done. The teachers should see that the children requiring dental attention are brought promptly to the Dentist in order that there will be no lost time or delay on the part of the Dentist. The Dentist should keep a list of the children given attention and the amount of the work done in each case. This you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

Regarding the case of George Shonenose who requires an operation for tonsils, you may arrange to have this done at a time considered suitable to have the work carried out. It may be that on the occasion of your next visit to the Reserve you could bring this boy back with you and have him sent to the place where the operation could be performed. You should arrange to see that the cost involved is kept down to the lowest possible point, and you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the operation and for any hospital charges.

The above matters will be left in your hands to have the necessary attention given, and it is expected that you will see that no large expense is incurred. The Department will be pleased to hear from you at a later date as to the action taken.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir,

I beg to advise that Miss Marcella Hickey teacher at the Sheeshagwaning R.C. School advises that she is unable to carry on her duties as teacher at that school as she is at present time very ill and the Doctor advises against her continuing on with the teaching.

MEMO FOR FILE:

On the 2nd instant I visited the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School and I found quite an interesting little community centre. This is a fairly good building, with a flashed roof, which is now giving trouble and concerning which the Agent will report. They have many outbuildings, nice flower and vegetable gardens and good equipment throughout. This school is a social centre for the older people of the reserve during the evenings. Miss LaVictoire, of the Nardene Order, and one assistant comprise the staff and they are proving a very good civilizing influence. They need a few desks and an extra bed, and, as these were surplus at the closed C. of E. School, I asked the Agent to send the equipment over. He is also to send a washstand to Little Current, to be picked up by Agent Lewis for the Kaboni School. I intend to authorize the Agent to purchase four stools for community purposes.

Ottawa, January 29, 1929.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, informing the Department that Miss Marcella Hickey, teacher of the Sheeshegunning R. C. Indian Day School, is giving up duties on account of ill-health and that she requests that Miss Valentine La Victoire be appointed as substitute teacher to succeed her until the end of the present academic year, viz., June 30th, next. The Department regrets that Miss Hickey finds it necessary to discontinue her duties.

It is noted that you have interviewed Miss La Victoire and that she has had teaching experience. The Department will approve of the temporary appointment of Miss La Victoire for the balance of the present school year only. It is hoped that Miss Hickey will be able to resume duties at the beginning of the next school year, but, if not, the services of a qualified teacher will be secured. The salary allowed Miss La Victoire for the period she teaches will be at the rate of $85 per teaching month.

I shall be pleased if you will state the date on which Miss Hickey gives up duties and the date on which Miss La Victoire takes over the teaching duties.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. F. Priddle, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cora Bay, Ont.

I have the honor to reply to
151713-5 Aug 6 to inform you that the
New School is a Frame Structure,
16' x 24' 6" with 9 feet walls on a wooden
foundation, and a small belfry on roof.

Outside Finish: Roof is shingled with
cedar shingles well laid.
Cornices are well put up pine treated
larch lumber.
Walls are shingled on felt paper or
sheeting. Cedar shingles. Corners have
around 1 inch pine board from bottom to
Cornish.
Lighting: 4 windows 2 sash each
6 panels to each 10x12
2 windows each side of Building.
Parker raised & lowered both bottom & top.

Entrance & Exit
1 door in end of Building well hung
Board material 4 panels
Covered by a temporary Porch
old Material.

Heating: 1 second-hand box stove
made some repairs but can be
used for cooking yet.
Under this there is no protection to
the floor from fire. The pipe leads
vertically up to ceiling. A hole has been
been cut & a tee with round hole 7" in for pipe cut. directly over this is a hole in the roof intended for a chimney but having now a tee roof cap.

Inside.

The floor is well laid & treated pine tongue and grooved.

Ceiling is matched Boarded & good natural dressed. One pipe hole & a movable trap door in north east corner to get up to loft.

Walls are wainscoted 3 feet high all round the room. No base boards or cornicing is on excepting the end for blackboard. There has cornicing window above that the ceiling is heavy felt paper backed on.

2 Blackboards are very poor and unsuitable for good work. 1 3ft by 5 ft is 8' across pure 4 inches wide and painted. 1 2ft by 3 feet is also painted pine painted.

The Teacher's desk is made of dressed pine with slanting top that 6'6" wide. School supplies are kept not very good.

Sanitary.

The water for drinking purposes came by a barrel from the lake distant about 60 yards.
Gentlemen:

Two have been erected Boardroom pine boards of good material and would be all right shipped.

There is no bell.

No painting has been done either inside or out.

Robert Thorburn

Wikwemikong, Ont.,
July 5, 1874.

Mr. Robert Thorburn,
Indian Agent,
Gore Bay.

Dear Sir: When in your office, in Gore Bay, last week I forgot to mention to you a suggestion made by His Lordship Bishop O'Connell as he visited the school at Sheshegwaning. It is the:
That it might be well to ask that a second floor be laid over the present one, with lining paper.
between, so as to make it warmer than it is. I hasten to write to you that you may reflect and if you think it well to mention it at the meeting which you will hold in She... on the 5th inst. If the meeting takes place in the school house, you will find, on examining, that the floor is rather poor. I left the key with Mr. Mr. Sampson.

When Mr. Shorburn Jr. was in She... on June 20th, I asked him for a lock and for the class-room cupboard; he told me to get one from Mr. Graham, which I did, also a pair of hinges for the storm house. Mr. Graham sent the enclosed account, with the articles, not knowing if you should have it, or if he will charge it to the Department. I send it to you, so you will know what to do about it.

Respectfully yours,

Edith Ducharme.
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose correspondence & maps & Michael teacher at the school, raising certain improvements needed there.

It seemed to me that the joint or fills under the floor were not sufficiently braced and supported, and though the material used is of good quality it is not sufficiently blocked to keep from opening.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

Robert Thorburn

[Stamp: Schools Aug 29 1904]

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 26 January

I have the honor to inform you that the present structures used as school and residence for teacher on the Sheshenqua reserve are totally inadequate to fill the requirements.

The school house is a small one story frame structure, 17' by 24 feet, cut full measurement, lights with 4 small windows and an 8 foot high ceiling; the accommodation is insufficient for the pupil attendance but from a sanitary point of view as well the blackboard space is too small, and if calculated with the other expenses we are to be continued, the house even more restricted.

The teachers residence is an old log house, very old and possibly 25° then it only one habitable room down stairs in width and all the cooking has to be done in it for the teacher's cooking class.

I would recommend the erection of a good substantial union residence-school-house and heated properly and in a more central location; the bulk of the lumber could be gotten out by the Indians and main factured for them or exchanged for other suitable building material.

Dear Kind Mr. MacKenzie,

If you happen to think of Fr. Papineau who had the pleasure of travelling with you last August, you probably ask to yourself if he might not be dead and buried. I am not dead nor dying but since I have left you with my skins in Manitoba ring, I have been so busy that I could never go to bed before midnight. I visit eleven missions every month; among others Shishigwaring, West Bay, South Bay and Wikwemikong, well known to you in account of their schools. Upon returning from the Wikwemikong oil wells you were telling me that I was in a position to do much for the schools in my missions. I have endeavoured since then to realize your word. During my monthly 300 mile tour around Manitoulin (i.e., from South Bay to Muldrew Bay) I remain three or four or five days in each of the four above mentioned great missions. I devote a good part of that monthly sojourn to the welfare of the schools. I teach Sunday-school daily; I question the children, give them rewards, and hustle them.

On Sunday, when preaching, I always have some recommendations to the Parent about the school, especially the attendance. In my numerous visits to the wigwams I insist very urgently on the school, and often bring some lost sheep back to the school room.

Saturdays, before winter, I generally took the boys with me and we would go in the forest to choose various kinds of trees that we afterwards planted around the church. The boys enjoy very much these object lessons. It is to the West-Bay school that I have given more time. Miss Mary Cushing, the West-Bay Teacher, is an excellent and zealous teacher but she is only a teacher. How much we miss the Sisters this year in West-Bay! It is when we are deprived of them that we fully appreciate these Religious who are teaching in Sagawag, Wikwemikong, Shishigwaning and South-Bay. The Missionary is the only one who can measure the amount of good the Sisters perform in the betterment of the Indians, and the awfully hard life they lead amongst those disgusting people. West-Bay is pretty well developed and polished, but Wikwemikong, Sagawag, South-Bay and Shishigwaning are the most lonely places. Being extremely busy as I am, I can easily stand five or six days in those midsts; but I really cannot understand how a refined
woman can remain eleven months with these vile people. I am practically the only white man that visit these three villages; and when I leave to come back only after a month, the two sisters often cry when quitting their homes. They are kept very busy; visiting the sick, organizing, giving sewing classes, etc., but what a social life! Drunkards, quarrellers, injure. In Shishigwining especially, Indians have drunk desperately this year, and the full children! One cannot imagine a worst collection of silly children in all intellectual matters. They reproduce hard-work very well, but where in intellectual subjects they are extremely obtuse.

I take leave to insist on the hardships of these sisters because I just have to beg you a favor that would contribute in rendering their life more supportable. It is about the residences of these sisters. They have needs that your department cannot easily think of. I wish to profit of your extraordinary kindness, and I would ask you to use your influence in making your Department adopt the plan that I will just temporarily submit to you.

They are very anxious about it at Wikwemikong South Bay and especially Shishigwining—and you will never imagine the comfort you would bring them if this sort of residence was executed. At present their residences are separated very awkwardly from the class-room. They would like immensely the following combination:
