Mr. J.D. McLean, Secretary Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Kind Mr. McLean,

I am pleased to acknowledge the receipt of your considerate answer to my communication of March 18th re the construction of a school and teachers residence in Sheeshawaning.

First of all I beg leave to thank you most heartily for your kindness in allowing me to make suggestions. Upon reading your first letter to me I experienced at once that all I have heard from our Fathers and the Indians about your exceptional kind-heartedness and devotedness to Indian affairs is perfectly true. Your extraordinary zeal for the welfare of our Odjibways is an object lesson to us.

We would accept with gratitude whatever you will deign grant to our teachers in Sheeshawaning or elsewhere; but since you condescend to hear furthermore our suggestions, I beg to say that our teachers find it impracticable to have their kitchen on the second floor — they have an absolute need of a cellar. They are obliged to bring with themselves, in August, their
food supplies for the whole year, e.g., in South Bay they are 16 miles from stores; in Sagamook they are 15 miles from nearest store, i.e., Massay; in Sheshegwaning they are 37 miles from the stores of Gore Bay and they can never rely upon the Indians to get their supply. To pack that food for the year, they need a good cool cellar and that cellar must be near the kitchen, because they have to go in at twenty times a day, to get milk, butter, vegetables, meat, etc., etc. The cook is often an elderly lady and it is morally impossible that she go down the stairs so many times a day. If they were in town where groceries can be obtained anytime, and where a small refrigerator is possible, it would be all right. But in those villages they must necessarily have a place to keep most of their food during eleven months, and I think the only practicable way to do so is to have a good cellar.

2° They would have to carry upstairs all the fuel, the water, etc., etc., very often without being able to obtain the help of the Indians; because when these Indians do not feel like it, they won't even split the wood in a reasonable way. I have often seen, this winter, pieces of fuel that no heather can carry up the stairs, and no Indian consented to split it better even for money.
For these reasons and others, they leave to suggest the enclosed plan.

This building would only be 45 feet long, i.e., only 10 feet longer than the one proposed by you.

Under the kitchen, the Parlor and the Oratory could be the cellar, divided in two: one part for the food and the other for the furnace—and a certain quantity of fuel; one single chimney could serve for both the furnace and the cooking stove. The furnace being (being) near the kitchen, it would be an easy task for the cook to keep up the fire.

I have suppressed the dining room because, having a waiting room, the teachers could be taking their meals in the kitchen and be protected from the curiosity of their every minute visitors.

The sliding door leading from the class-room to the Oratory could form a black-board and thus leave the full 24 ft wall for boards.

I have suggested a separate porch for girls and boys because it's almost necessary for good morality among our so precocious Indian children that the girls should be separated from the boys in the porches as well as in their playgrounds. In Shesheyawaging, West-Bay and South-Bay, to avoid disorders in the bush, we have begun to let the girls go home, 10 long minutes before the boys.
I am writing these suggestions with velvet gloves, as it were. Even if you throw them in the wastebasket, we shall always be grateful to you for your past great favor, dear Mr. Maclean. However, if you do not judge proper to grant a kitchen downstairs i.e., on the ground floor, I would beg you to leave the oratory near the class-room, but not to provide for a kitchen on the first floor. The teachers will, in that case, collect some alms, to build at their own expense, a kitchen on the ground floor. They declare it morally impossible to have the kitchen upstairs. They have tried it, in the school of West Bay; but they were obliged to build a kitchen on the ground floor.

In the plan I am just suggesting, the ceiling of the Oratory, the Hall and the Kitchen would be three feet lower than that of the class-room, so as to allow two very reasonable bed-rooms above the lower ceiling without making the whole building higher.

Hoping that the enclosed rough plan is clear enough and thanking you, in advance, for whatever you may grant, I remain

Very Sincerely Yours,

Eug. A. Papineau, Jr.

Mr. Oliver.

In the early part of the season the Department prepared plans and specifications for a combined school-house and teacher's residence at Sheshegwaning, Manitoulin Island, and the Council of the Band passed a resolution authorizing an expenditure of a sufficient amount from their funds to put up the building. The estimated cost was $4000.00. Tenders were called for and only one was received. This was from Halcombe & Co. and amounted to $6650.00. The Indians have expressed a request that they be allowed to do this work on this building and that the walls be of concrete instead of frame as originally provided for. Inquiries have been made and the Indian Agent, Mr. Thorburn, states that a reliable contractor named Mr. Clark would undertake the supervision of the work by Indian labour with the assistance of one of his own men. Suitable materials for the concrete work are available and Mr. Clark has estimated the cost at $3850.00.

I would recommend that advantage be taken of Section 36.
36 of Chapter 39 of the Public Works Act and that concrete be substituted for lumber and that the work be done by day labour under the supervision above stated. This will be an encouragement to the Indians, who are supplying the necessary funds, and will be a benefit to them from both a practical and pecuniary standpoint.

Ottawa, July 27, 1911.

Sir,

I beg to confirm the following telegram sent you yesterday:— "Will building Sheeshewaning school of concrete by day labour under Mr. Clark's supervision. Work should be started at once. An advance for wages with full instructions going forward by mail."

In view of the request of the Indians it has been decided to perform this work by day labour under Mr. Clark's supervision. The Department prefers to pay Mr. Clark a stated wage per day, he to arrange for his own board and lodging. You will, therefore, be good enough to obtain from him a rate of wages equivalent to the amount mentioned in your letter, viz., $3.50 per day and board. It is understood that Mr. Clark will work continuously himself on the job. He should engage his own helper and all the rest of the labour so far as is practicable should be performed by the Indians.

Concrete will be substituted for frame in the walls, the specifications to be amended to conform with the suggestions contained in the first paragraph of your letter of July 11th, last, in which the dimensions of the walls are given.

You will be required to visit the school while the building is under construction as often as possible to see that the work is being done in accordance with the plans.

R. Thorburn, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gore Bay, Ont.

Dear Sir:— I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th inst.
No. 151713-5.

In answer, I respectfully beg to make the following remarks:

I know very well that the proximity of the church has only a secondary connection with the schools of your Department, and I would never have alluded to it if Mr. Thorburn had not first spoken to me about it.

After my arrival here, he suspended the work, called a meeting of the Indians, and asked them if they were willing to build a church near the school. He came...
to make the following proposition to me:
"If the Indians build their church in
the neighborhood of the school, are you
willing to go in the bush?"— I told
Mr. Thorburn that I would give him
my answer later on.— I thought that
Mr. Thorburn had made you aware of
his proposition. Having been exhorted
by Rev. Father Papineau to accept Mr.
Thorburn's offer, for the sake of peace,
I thought it better to wire my answer
to you in order to hasten your decision.
I realize that my telegram must have
appeared strange to you, since you
were not aware of Mr. Thorburn's
proposal.

You may find it strange that the
proximity of a church would change
my opinion about the location of the
school. The reason is this— The site of
the new school is so lonely, not a single
house can be seen from it. I naturally
think that the church being in the neighborhood would necessarily make it a less lonesome spot. Believe me, dear Mr. McLean, it is not through a stubborn caprice that I was opposed going in the new school. I have just given the ten best years of my life to the welfare of Shishigwaming; this is a sufficient proof of my good will. But I have not the Indian nature, and I feared that a sojourn in the wilderness, added to the unparalleled ingratitude of the Indians, as shown every day, would turn me crazy.

I would be greatly sorry to have appeared to dictate a line of conduct to your Department. I fought against the location in the bush, because I knew the majority was against it. You have been told that the whole Band had accepted it; and I know that your Department will listen to the report.
of the Agent in preference to everyone else, but it is a sure fact that at the first meeting, Gabriel Niganivine, Ignatius Metategaiaask, Joseph Sampson, Frank Javenashi, Amable Wabigone, Andrew Wabigone, John Gaboni, Joseph Metategaiaask, Louis Okeda, Wilson Sampson, William Cook, Noel Dominic, Dan Niganivine, William Wakaosse, John Okeda, Alex Vincent, Antoine Wabigijig, Alex Wabigijig and Peter Okeda, were not invited. Little by little, the chief and his noisy clique worked such pressure over the timid others, that they tolerated the second and nearer spot chosen. — I do not mention this irreceivable fact to find fault with your decision, but simply to explain the strong stand I had taken.

I can never be grateful enough for your kindness, Mr. M. Lean, in designing to give us the excellent accommodations.
you so royally granted in the new school. To show my gratitude to you, in the hope of having a church there as promised by Mr. Thorburn, and also to listen to the entreaties of Rev. Father Papineau, I shall go there to teach this year at least.

Most sincerely yours,

Adèle Ducharme

Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that I have had the work of erecting the school fairly well inspected. The builder is doing exceptionally good work considering the unskilled workmen employed. The enclosed pay rolls for October week No. 17290 completed the work up to bottom window on top story. I left them today and the walls are completed to the rafters and rafters will be put up tomorrow and a part of the gable put in as soon as the roof can be put on. It is intended to complete all the outside work if possible. The erection of the porch, finish coat on the cement wall outside entrance to cellar etc before the frost gets heavy.

The isolated place the school is in is costing slightly more for transportation than was anticipated but the arrangement made still gives the freight at least 140% less than the settlers are paying to the regular wharf 5 miles farther out the harbor.

It has been found that the measurements of the two flats do not correspond by about 6 inches the discrepancy was noted and corrected before any damage was done. The extra heavy fell timber ordered in the construction plans is making a very strong...

I have the honor to enclose payrolls for weeks ending October 28th $121.03

Nov 4th 92.22

The work has been very much hampered by the broken weather, every effort being made to get ready for winter and if it is found that satisfactory progress is not being made after next week when it is expected to have the furnace in I would suggest that the work be closed down until March.

The last cheque for $251 for 500 in wages has just arrived. I will leave for the steamer in the morning and report from there Saturday morning if possible on the progress made thus far with the exception of last week all work has been done for considerably less than could have been done by a contractor. A revision of the cost of the materials will show in most cases a considerable reduction on cost of the local prices and the cement of best grade at first wholesale cost less the freight which is not usually allowed. There will be an overplus of cement nearly half a car. This will be taken over by Mr. Clark and in the item alone a big saving has been made by obtaining first costs prices.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, February 27, 1912.

Sir,

Referring to official letter of April 21st, last, in which an expenditure of $12.50 per annum for prizes for the West Bay and Sheshagwaning School was authorized, purchases to be made quarterly, I beg to say that the intention was that $6.25 should be spent on each school during the year. You will be good enough to advise them accordingly and see that the accounts do not exceed this amount.

MEMORANDUM:-

Mr. Agent Thorburn asks that an officer of the Department be sent to Manitoulin Island to inspect the work on the new school and teacher's residence in course of erection at Sheshegwaning. The building is being put up by day labour and is nearing completion and should be examined before the plastering is done and the finished floors laid.

As no provision for a water supply in the building is made the bath and stationary washstand shown on the plans could be omitted and an old fashioned tin bath tub and washstand with enamelled chamber set be substituted. Mr. Chene, who prepared the plans, states "As the plans of the Sheshegwaning School had to be prepared without any description of the ground where this building was to be erected no provision could be made on plans or specifications for the drainage of the basement and sewage water, but the same could easily be attended to before..."
"before building is completed, if an officer would make the
"necessary inquiries as to the best and most economical
"arrangement to be considered for the completion of the
"work."

Mr. Agent Thorburn says the inspection
should be made now so that any alterations or deviations
from the specifications could be adjusted with very little
trouble, which would entail considerable expense later on.
He no doubt refers to the upper flat, which is to be
used for the teacher's quarters. The teacher may have
some suggestions to make as to the laying out of the
rooms. Changes could be made now without additional
expense before the partitions are up and plastering done.

As neither Mr. Chene nor Mr. Ogilvie can
leave the work they are now engaged on I might go on from
Belleville next week and report on the work already done
and see what changes or alterations in the interior arrange-
ment are necessary. I have gone carefully over the
plans and specifications with Mr. Chene, who considers
that I would be quite competent to make the inspection.

MEMORANDUM:

I reached Gere Bay by the "City of Midland" on Friday morning, the 31st ultimo. When I got there I found that Mr. Agent Therburn had been superseded by Mr. Frank Baxter. Mr. Baxter secured a gasoline launch and accompanied by Mr. Clarke, the foreman engaged by the Department for the erection of the school building at Sheshegwaning, we proceeded to Sheshegwaning, distant from Gere Bay some 26 miles by water and arrived there early in the afternoon. We called on Miss Duhamel, the teacher of the school.

There were ten children in attendance at the school, seven boys and three girls. I examined them and found them so shy that I could hardly make out what they were endeavouring to say. As I was anxious to visit the new school I got Miss Duhamel to dismiss the pupils and she accompanied us up the road back from the lake to the site of the new school.

The building is well under way and it is a most imposing structure, being built of concrete on a stone foundation, is 50 feet by 27 feet and is a story and a half high. The site is well chosen as to drainage and is about as central as can be had.
had. The lathing was all done and there is only the plastering and the laying of the hardwood floors needed to complete the interior of the building. Cement rendering had been completed on a portion of the outside walls to represent stone masonry and the remainder of the walls will be finished in the same manner. The sills were not placed, but single block concrete sills were ready to be put in position. The whole of the basement has a concrete floor and a large concrete tank has been built across the southwest corner of the building near the stairway.

The heating and ventilation plant was all in position and is thoroughly modern. The furnace installed is a McClarey furnace, 1904 model, No. 416a. On the first floor there is a large bath-room with stationary enamel tub and wash-stand and all modern appliances and connected with the tank in the basement by a force pump. The account of Jackson & Company, who did this work, would show that no expense has been spared in making a thoroughly up-to-date job.

All the material to complete the building is on hand except some lime to be used in the plastering. The lime supplied by the Indians Mr. Clarke did not consider was good enough quality to be used. I am attaching some prints which show the old and the new school buildings.

There were some slight changes made in the layout of the building for the convenience of the teacher and her assistant. The Oratory was reduced in size and a portion laid out for a dining-room.
dining-room. A door was cut from the hallway into the school-room on the south side and the linen room was divided so as to leave sufficient closet room and to make another bed room.

The outside closets are well built and have concrete pits seven feet deep. They are not screened as the teacher and the Priest say they are better left open to view. They are placed one hundred feet back from the school. The whole of the ground is high and drains have been dug and tiled from the school building and closets and there is ample space for a good playground on the north side. The ground should be fenced when the building is completed.

There is an enrolment of 30 pupils at this school, which is about the full number of children of school age that could attend and the average for last year was 15. The school-room in the new building has seating capacity for 40 and could easily hold 10 more without overcrowding. I was forced to the conclusion that it is much in excess of the needs of the reserve. It is a very handsome and well constructed building, but too good for the place. It has cost up to the present time $4177.26. There are unpaid accounts amounting to $306.24 for the heating, plumbing and ventilating plant, in addition to which there will be the cost of the plasterers' wages as skilled workmen will have to be secured. I doubt if the whole building will be completed for less than $5000.00. $4500.00 was the estimated cost. The work so far has all been done by Indian labour under the guidance of
of Mr. Clarke, who is a practical builder and contractor and a thoroughly competent man. I am surprised that Agent Thorburn should have recommended such an expensive building for this reserve, as a smaller and cheaper building would have answered the purpose and would not have looked out of place. The old school and residence is more in keeping with its surroundings.

Martin Benson

Respected Sir:

I waited till we were settled in the new school to write to thank you for it and for the comfort so kindly afforded us. I received the keys of the school Sept. 26th and moved into it on the 27th. I cannot adequately express my gratitude to you, knowing as I do, the many annoyances which you have had to bear and which may continue for some time.

I heartily thank you for your firmness in not heeding the false and antagonistic reports which you have received at different times, in regard to the school. Your experience in dealing with the Indians no doubt restrained you from yielding to
these few malcontents, as their example might be followed by such people in other places. I should not, perhaps, refer to the subject since you have not requested me to do so; but I feel it my duty to inform you that nine children of the troublesome party of five families, are not in school; one of these is not quite six years of age and two are nearly fifteen; these last will probably not go to school again. Will the others be allowed to grow up ignorant? I do not think you will tolerate it. Five of these were in school before and did very well indeed, for the time they were here, and the complaints are groundless.

I regret that the school Inspector has not been here this fall; I trust he may yet come; first to see the work done by the children, also to note several defects in the new building. I might mention one which I find most important: All the windows are made to open only from the bottom; the top can be moved only
by breaking a strip which keeps in
and which, the men say, is inserted
½ in. into the frame. The Agent came
this week. I had a man at work
taking out a side strip and sand-
papering the varnish off the bottom
sash; the windows were not opened after
the woodwork was varnished but were
let dry closed. Mr. Baxter suggested sav-
ing that strip which keeps the top part
in but he said it would have to be
put in again and taken out every time
we wash the windows. The man was
afraid to attempt it and preferred to
wash the outside of the tops for us, as
we cannot reach. I doubt if the De-
partment will approve hiring a man
every time we wash windows.

Mr. Baxter told me that you have
written to him regarding a well; I shall be most
grateful if it can be dug before
winter. At present, we have fire in the
furnace only a part of the day, it
takes at least three pails of water;
you may reckon from that how
much will be required when we have
fire all day. It takes fully fifteen
minutes to go to the nearest well for water, and it is the poorest of roads in winter.

The children are doing well in school. I received the supply for the cooking and sewing class only two weeks ago, but we had these lessons regularly since the reopening of school. I had some print with which the girls made aprons; they are now crocheting mittens for themselves and for the boys. When these are finished, they will make dresses, then shirts.

Most gratefully yours,

Adèle Ducharme.

Respected Sir:

Your very kind letter of the 22nd received yesterday.

The cheque for the sum of seventy-six (76) dollars which you mention, was received by Joseph McKategaishk on March 10th. This is not the account of which I spoke to you. Not having wood enough for the furnace, I asked for fifteen cords more. Mr. Agent Baxter not acting, I thought it best to write to Mr. Parker who came to Shoegwanning in February, and who knew we really needed the wood. The Department, as usual, answered promptly. Just at that time the Indians were making ties on the Reserve, and were not anxious to cut the wood unless I promised to pay, because it took so long to get the cheque from the Department. I agreed to advance the money and Joseph McKategaishk again took the contract, he got several men to help, so the fifteen cords were brought in a few days.
Mr. Baxter happened to be in Skeeshog during and at the school when Joseph brought the last load, I made out the account, had it signed, and gave it to Mr. Baxter who promised to forward it to the Department at once. As I have not my diary here, I cannot give you the exact date of the account; it was either March 28th or April 4th. Joseph was to give me the cheque when he received it.

It might be as well for me to mention the other accounts due. One, three and five dollars for work done by Wilson Sampson—putting up window shades. The Agent brought them only in spring though they were in Gore Bay since last fall. I did not write an account for this amount, for the Agent told me that he would send the account to the Department himself. I do not know if he sent it in Wilson Sampson's name or mine; he knew that I paid it.

I have received no money for caretaking of the classroom (sweeping, etc.) since last October, for the September quarter. When we moved into the new school, last September I told the Agent I thought the caretaking of the school was worth more than twelve dollars a year, this one being so much larger than the old school; he said that
twenty dollars had been granted for the West Bay school and he thought the same amount would be given us. He said he would write to the Department about it, but never gave me a definite answer. In March, the girl who did the sweeping wanted to stop because she had not received any money yet, so I paid her for the December and March quarters and did the same at the end of June and sent the account in my name.

Another account is for caretaking of the furnace. Mr. Baxter told me, last fall, that the Department would allow four dollars a month for that work. I could not depend on an Indian to do the work, I would have had to look after him, as well, so I preferred to do it with the aid of Miss Lutz who was staying with me and to get help when it was necessary. I sent in the account of this in Miss Lutz's name, for five months, although we had to have fire in the furnace much longer.

I will give you, as you kindly requested, a list of the furniture we need:

1 single iron bedstead with spring mattress
12 day chairs, I would be pleased to have one of these, a rocker.

1 long handled brush to wash windows (the top sash of the windows cannot be moved. I would be grateful if they could be put on pulleys.)
Also 2 rollers for window shades. I have not the measurements here, but I think rollers in windows of ordinary width will do, as they are not for the widest windows.

Thanking you most sincerely for your prompt and thoughtful attention, I am,

Gratefully yours,

Adèle Duhamel.

Dear Sir,

The furnace in our school did not work well all last year.

Mr. Parker promised to send a man to have the trouble remedied. I waited until Christmas, but as lately there has been a smell of scorching wood I did not think it safe to wait any longer.

Nearly all the heat of the furnace went to the bath-room upstairs. I made an opening in this pipe so as to allow this heat.
to go to the class-room.

There being no register I had to close an opening in a room that is not used much and use this register in the class-room.

On the 30th of December I went to see Mr. Baxter at Rose Bay and told him what I had done. He asked me to make all the repairs needed about the school, that he would come in a week or two to get an account of my time.

Mr. Baxter said there was a check damper needed in the furnace so I made one.

A great deal of heat left the class-room, especially on
windy days so I made a trap door for the ventilator. The furnace pipes came apart a number of times in several places. I made them secure by bracing them with wooden supports.

The grate of the furnace was cracked in two places and was in danger of falling so I repaired it.

As the school grounds have not yet been cleared and the children had no place to play I cleared a small strip on which they could slide.

Having not the proper tools for some of the work it took me a long time to do it.
I have worked 5 days and would like $2 a day. As Mr. Baxter has not come yet I thought it best to send the report to the Department direct. Hoping that all is satisfactory, I remain,

Very respectfully yours,
Wilson Sampson
Chief

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir: You did quite right to deduct from my salary for the September Quarter, the sum of twelve and five dollars which I still owed on the money so kindly advanced to me by the Department in July, 1913. I was about to write to tell you this when I received your letter.

As I closed my accounts during the holidays, I found that I sent the Department the bill for rewards for the September Quarter, 1913, twice—in October, 1913, and again in June last, and both times received the sum of two and five dollars. Therefore, I did not send the bill for the rewards for the last September Quarter, but got the rewards just the same.

You wrote me last July that you had written Mr. Baxter, Indian Agent at Gore Bay, for a voucher for the small amount due me for rewards for the June Quarter, 1913, for the Shechequoming School. He evidently has not sent it and probably will not, at this late date. I shall not trouble you again by mentioning the fact, for if it depends on him, I shall not get it. He has ignored...
the different letters I wrote him on the subject. His oft repeated negligence are worthy of note.

The new floor in the classroom is finished and is very nice; before the men began the work, I asked the agent if the floor was to be oiled; he said he feared he would not have enough money, so I had the school boys take up the desks which were screwed to the old floor and take them out of the room. I also made them take out the old lumber, to save the men's time; but I asked the agent for linseed oil and I oiled the floor with the help of the boys; we also painted the new cupboard. The work is not quite finished, as soon as the agent sends window fasteners, the men will come one day more.

I am very grateful to the Department for granting me an assistant; I expect Miss Kelly early this week.

The children, I think, are doing very well; on account of the large number, I had to give sewing and crocheting lessons after school twice a week. The girls have each a pair of mittens finished; five are now crocheting wristlets to send to the Patriotic League, Little Current, for the Canadian soldiers. Last Thursday, at the usual lesson, we cut under skirts and under garments for all the girls. When these are finished the girls will make shirts for the boys.
I will begin the sewing class for the ex-pupils as soon as harvest work is over.

In spite of difficulties in spring, the school garden was quite a success. From one bag of potatoes which we planted, we got eleven bags. All those who had gardens took home radishes, lettuce and carrots all summer; this fall, each had about one half bag of turnips, beets, etc. The little ones of the general garden had a good share of corn, beets and turnips to take home. We try at the cooking lesson, to make use of the garden things; thus, for one lesson the girls had to shell beans, cut corn off the cobs and make soup. They also made pickles with small musk melons and radish pods, and all took a bottle home. This week they will make citron preserves, and take some home; they have also made tomato preserves. The parents greatly appreciate these lessons.

I wish to thank you, also for the increase in my salary.

Most sincerely yours,

Adèle Dubuc.

Oct. 30, 1914

Dear Sir,

The work of drilling the well at the Roman Catholic school was begun yesterday and I am most grateful to the Department for it. Some of our Indians though are very much disappointed to find that only the schools are to have wells and several have asked me to intercede for them with the Department.

Our chief, Wilson Sampson, told me last year that he had asked for three wells for the Indians and expected that they would be dug when the ones at the schools were.

Many of these people live a great deal farther from the water than we do. From my first coming here I have tried in every way to encourage our people.
to build on farms. William Cook has just finished a house and Raphael Riggiwina is just beginning one on a farm, or rather what is to become a farm. Several others already living on farms have to come through the village to the bay for all their water. The distance from water is a great drawback to farm life here.

If the department could have several wells dug at centres where several families could easily reach them it would be a great help. The men who are doing the drilling of our wells expect to remain about two weeks, so if the Department see fit to have more work done they might be glad to have it done while the drill is here.

Thanking you for any favor you may bestow on our Indians, I remain,

Very respectfully yours,
Elizabeth Dewar

The sight for the proposed well at our school is about 38 ft. from the closet. I would be grateful to know if there is any danger of the water becoming contaminated.

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter No. 15713 of the 30th ult., and wish to thank you for the same.

Our Indian Agent Mr. Bastie brought the windows for the new house, the cooking and sewing supplies on the 27th ult., and promised to return the following Thursday with the grate for the furnace and to make the necessary repairs. But he has not come yet.

I am not able to heat the class-room properly for want of grate.

Both Joel Domenic and I are anxiously waiting for the cheque in payment for the bills, the duplicates of which I sent in my last letter. As the Indians here have no work at present and are in need of money, I have advanced all I could on the work done at the school.

I am sorry to have to trouble you again, dear Mr. MacKenzie, but Joel Domenic has not yet received pay for the work he did for the school last spring and summer.

I sent the first bill to Mr. Baxter at the beginning of July, the second in September. On the 20th of December I gave Mr. Baxter duplicates of the other three bills enclosed. I am forwarding these to you in case that he has not sent the others.

Mr. Baxter has been very careless lately. I have been obliged to write several times to the Department about supplies I had asked for but not received.
He brought nearly all a few days ago but the pump in the bath-room and the repairs of the plaster have not yet been attended to.

But the money, just now, is the most important. I have been obliged to advance some to keep us he could not wait so long.

All at the school goes on as usual. Last week the children gave an entertainment which Father Capricorn, Mr. Baxter as well as the Indians found good.

Distribution of prizes took place at the same time. Instead of having prizes for September quarter we have both at Christmas. The children choose what they wish for from the catalogue. They enjoy it very much. I have done this the past five years and find it good.

Hoping that I am not giving you, dear Mrs. Macdonald, too much trouble, remain

With best wishes for the New Year,

Very respectfully yours,

Elizabeth Lenzel.

Jan. 31, 1916

Dear Mr. MacKenzie,

Last mail brought me your kind letter and also Noel Dominic's cheque for $30.60 and John Simon's for $2.20.

I am very grateful for all especially to you for your great kindness in seeing to the matter at once.

Through my fault there was, however, an error made. I had put Noel's bill for $17.05 of July and the one of September for $15. on the same sheet of paper. The one of September was overlooked.

His cheque of $30.60 pays July bill of $17.05 for work done last spring and December bill of $13.55 for work done upstairs and at his house.
The bill of $15. for clearing bare fall grounds still remains unpaid.

I am very sorry I caused this extra work and disorder in the accounts by not using an separate sheet for each bill but as I had sent duplicates several times of these bills I did not think it necessary.

Again thanking you, dear Mr. MacKenzie for your great kindness,

I remain,

Most respectfully yours,

Elizabeth Leuck.

Memorandum.

Ottawa, July 14, 1916.

Mr. McLean,

When at Sheshewaning Reserve recently, I incidentally called at the schools in passing and beg to report as follows:

The buildings and grounds at the Roman Catholic school are in splendid condition and the school garden is exceptionally fine reflecting great credit on the teacher and pupils.

The attendance is small, only 12 pupils I was told.

The money recently spent on fencing and clearing the grounds has been well expended and Miss Leusch requested me to ask the Department to allow her $15.00 per annum for the clearing of the grounds on west side of schoolhouse where there is still left some trees and underbrush. There is a well cleared space on this side for athletic purposes and swings are erected, the cleared space is quite ample for the present and much more spacious than is usually found around a schoolhouse in the country. I think the pupils and some of the fathers should be interested enough and see by example what can be done, to do any more.
more clearing that may be necessary and I cannot recommend the expenditure annually but would recommend that $15.00 be allowed for this year.

A lawn mower is necessary and Rev. Papineau has loaned one to the teacher which he is willing to sell, Miss Leusch informed me. She thought it worth $5.00 but I think $5.00 would be a fair and reasonable price for it and I would recommend purchasing it at this price, ($5.00). Miss Leusch said Department had authorized her to have someone care for garden during vacation, but I would suggest that Noel Dominic be paid for cutting the lawn and the Indians look after the garden plots themselves.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Referring to your letter of 5th inst I beg to report that I visited the Sheshegwaning R.C.School and found that the original hot air pipes in school room are intact but as they never heated the room Miss Leusch having failed to get any change made had an Indian tap a pipe going to bathroom spreading the tim to sides and put in a Register from upstairs there being no register box or other protection at the top of hole and being only 3 feet from the furnace hence the fire, I gave orders at the time to disconnect this pipe so that they could use the furnace and found thiadone and opening sealed up at furnace, and as Miss Leusch says that this pipe to bath room is not necessary the only difficulty is in getting the school heated. There are four Registers in School room and as they are from 30 to 50 feet long and run that distance on a dead level it is needless to say they never heated anything and never will, these Registers are 7 ft from floor and two of them extend to upstairs and serve as ventilators to carry the foul air to the dwelling, the upstairs heats all right, the cold air pipes are not large enough for capacity of hot air pipes, and one takes the cold air from the lobbies and is twin part to furnaces, the one is used principally for a cuspidor for the pupil tobacco chewers.

Ottawa, September 18th, 1920.

Mr. Sutherland -

Sir,

I beg to advise that Miss Leusch, Sheshewanganing R.C.School, wishes three shelves put in cellar, for the purpose of storing canned fruit and vegetables, which they put up for their use, 2 ft deep and 17 ft long, the cost would be about $8. or $10.

Also lining for kitchen stove.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ottawa, September 22, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, in which you state that Miss Leusch, teacher of the Sheshegwaning (R.C.) Indian Day School, wishes to have three shelves put in the cellar for the purpose of storing canned fruit and vegetables.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have the shelves required by Miss Leusch put up and the expense for doing the work should not exceed your estimate of $10.00.

You may also arrange to have a new lining put in the kitchen stove and this work should be done as cheaply as possible.

As soon as the shelves are erected and the lining placed in the kitchen stove you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Miss Leusch has had bins erected in the cellar for storage purposes and she has been informed that, if she will send in her account for the expenditure incurred by her for the purpose, she will be reimbursed. Her account should be forwarded through your office, which you will be good enough to certify and forward to the Department, in order that payment can be made her.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of the material used, and time sheets, in duplicate, for the labour employed should also be forwarded. If you will state the name of the manufacturer of the double desks, we will then be able to place an order for ink wells of the size to suit the desks.

We hope that you will be able to arrange to have the painting required carried out at both this school and the Anglican school at a very reasonable cost.

There is no woodshed at this school. Don't you think one should be built? The wood becomes so wet in the fall and winter that a woodshed is a necessity.

It appears as if the rain had entered through the roof. Upstairs plaster is marked with it. It might be looked into before it is too late. If it was my own house I would certainly attend to it.

J. M. Bennett,
Insp.
Ottawa, Sept. 21st, 1923.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School, recommends that a woodshed be built for the use of the school. He states that the wood becomes so wet in the fall and winter that a woodshed is a necessity. I shall be pleased if you will state your views regarding this matter, and if you think that a woodshed should be erected, you should state the approximate size and type of building you would recommend, and the probable cost of the same. This matter should receive your prompt attention, in order that, if it is decided to put up a building, the work can be done before the cold weather sets in.

The Inspector further states that the rain has entered through the roof of the teacher's living quarters, and the upstairs plaster is marked with it. He states that repairs to the roof are urgently needed, in order to prevent further damage to the plaster. You will be good enough to see that the roof is placed in good condition in order to prevent leakage. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred for the purpose, and this matter should receive your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. R. McGregor, Esq.,
Indian Agent

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 21st instant re woodshed at R.C.School, Sheshegwaning, I beg to advise that I have taken up the matter of same with Miss O'Driscoll, and she would like one built next Spring, as the winter wood for kitchen is nicely piled convenient to back door and she would not want to go to the expense of moving it into the wood shed when built, but if built next Spring the new wood could be piled in when split.

The furnace wood could not be placed in it as it is too far from cellar entrance.

I would consider that a shed 12x16 would be large enough for the kitchen wood, would advise that it be built on cedar sills so next teacher could have it moved if she wishes, as it cannot be built at rear close to building, owing to kitchen and dining room windows, so would have to be detached.

As regards cost it is difficult getting lumber there but it could be cut at Meldrum Bay this winter and teamed down and sills could also be got on the ground during the winter all being done cheaper during sleighing. I could not at the present time give an estimate of cost, but it being small would not run into much money, almost impossible to get shingles there but roofing could be used.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ottawa, September 29th, 1923.

Sir:

We are very surprised that you keep on repaired that Anglican school here. They is only 2 boys and 1 girls total & why the Department of Indian Affairs do not close up the Anglican schools here it is not enough children to have two schools here in our Reserve.

We wish you satisfied us why you are keep on repaired the school no children etc.

Very Respectfully Yours,

Chief Wilson Sampson

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, regarding the woodshed required for the purpose of storing the wood for kitchen use at the Sheshegwaning R.C. Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that, unless you consider this woodshed is absolutely required, you should not undertake the work of building the same. If, however, it is necessary, only an inexpensive building for the purpose should be erected.

Your recommendation that both the Roman Catholic and Anglican Schools be closed on account of the small attendance, and the children placed in residential schools, has been noted. It would, no doubt, be difficult to close the Roman Catholic School, and it will have to be continued in operation for some time. Regarding the Anglican School, the Department is communicating with His Grace the Archbishop of Algoma with a view to having him consent to its closing and having the children placed in the Shingwauk Home. Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

From the commencement of the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School, all current expenses were paid from Band Funds, Account No. 247, until the fiscal year 1910-11, when a portion of the salary was paid from Appropriation. I am unable to ascertain why the change was made. From 1910, a part of the salary and also some other current expenses (approximately 50% of the total cost of conducting the school) were paid from Appropriation, until the fiscal year 1919-20, when all the salary was paid from the Band Funds. EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON THE SHESHGWAN-
ING INDIAN DAY SCHOOL, MAY 13, 1925.

For the first time in my visit here I nearly stumbled going up the stairs and then discovered the reason. Each step is a ten inch one in height when the average is 4". I cannot see how ladies can regularly use these without finally injuring their health. The landing room upstairs is used for an exhibit room, and for germinating and growing early vegetables. Both pupils and teacher use these stairs. I would recommend that 6" stairs be made as soon as possible.

Kitchen might be painted in colors asked by teacher. The stairs should be attended to.

The present kitchen stove has been in use for 18 years at least and is not good for baking. I would suggest a modern range and allow the teachers to suggest the kind they want.

J. M. Bennett,
Inspector.

Please report whether you would recommend that the kitchen be painted and a range provided. If so, you should state the approximate cost of the material and labour required in painting the kitchen and the cost of a range.

Sir:

On Saturday 22nd inst I visited Sheshogwanning and took a competent carpenter with me to look at the stairway in the R. C. School and found that the stairs now are a good nine inch rise and nine inch tread and in order to reduce this to a seven inch rise and still use the nine inch tread, which would have to be done as less than a nine inch tread would be of no use the doorway at the bottom of stairs leading into the kitchen would have to be moved and there would have to be quite a lot of new material gotten as the wainscoting new on would have to be torn off and there would have to be new banisters and some new spindles for the railing and some new wainscoting and material for some new steps.

The whole stairway would have to be taken down and rebuilt and the cellar steps also as they are the same rise as the others but of course they would not be such a job.

Your authority to have these alterations are in letter dated Sept, 17th and also authority in letter of July 18th for steps over fence these letters numbered 12-3-8 and 12-3-5 respectively.

I can obtain two competent men in the vicinity to do the work but as they would have to drive about seven miles night and morning they will not work for less than 60 cents an hour.

I do not estimate that the main stairs in the school and the cellar stairs and the steps at the pump can be done less than $150.00 and it might be a little more. You could ask Mr Phalen re this as he saw the steps and interviewed me re same.

Would like to know soon if it is all right to go to this much expenditure in connection with the above. The teacher is very anxious to have this done at once.

Sir:

On Saturday 22nd inst when I visited Sheshegwaning Miss Hickey the teacher at the R. C. School had me look at their well pump and I found it in very bad shape.

The casting at the top of pump that holds the handle, etc has been so badly broken and parts of it lost at different times that they do not use same at all and at present time have a sort of a scaffold built over the pump with three small pieces of timber and have a wire running down from it and another wire on the sucker rod of the pump and use a stick for a handle using the wire running down from the scaffold as a leverage, the sucker rod has become so worn at the threads down inside of pump that it comes right out every little while.

I do not know if the cylinder is worn out or not but Miss Hickey says that it is terribly hard to pump the water.

As there are several families use the pump for their water I would suggest and recommend a new pump head at least which can be bought for $10.00 and still use the old cylinder if any good and if it was found to be no good upon lifting pump a new pump with cylinder and all could be got for around $18.00

This pump was repaired some time last spring and as it is used so much and is so old that I do not think it advisable to try and have repaired, in any case the casting at top would have to be got new and also some new sucker rods or those other's newly threaded so that I believe for all the extra cost to get a new pump it would be a lot more satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Indian Agent

Ottawa, October 28, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, reporting on the condition of the pump in the well at the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School.

It is considered, in view of your report, that it would be advisable to have a new pump installed, and you may arrange for the purchase and installation of same. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained and the purchase of a pump of a satisfactory type should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. After the pump has been supplied, you should arrange to have same installed in the well. It is not thought that it would be advisable to have the present old pump fitted up with a new head and cylinder, but that it would be more satisfactory to install a new pump. After this pump has been obtained and installed in the well, you should forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, covering the cost.

I have also your letter regarding the stairway in the school building and the cellar steps. With reference to reducing the height of the tread, I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work carried out. You may purchase any material required for the purpose, including new bannisters and spindles for the railing, also any new wainscoting and other material. We note that you can obtain the services of two competent men in the vicinity to do the work, and that you estimate the cost of altering the main stairs in the school and the cellar stairs and the steps at the pump to be approximately $150. You should arrange to have this work carried out at an early date. All expense should be kept as low as possible. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the necessary alterations in the stairs at the lowest possible cost. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the amount due for the labour and for the material should be forwarded.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. P. Friddle, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Gore Bay, Ont.

Sir;-

I beg to advise that Miss Hiskey, teacher at the R. C. School Shehewanan asked me yesterday if it was possible to have some kalsomine done at the school. There are three rooms upstairs and the hall and stairway downstairs that have not been done for several years and I would say by the looks of same that it needs doing very bad. It would probably take eight or ten packages of kalsomine and three or four days labour as there are some cracks that should be filled with plaster of paris.

The window frames and sash should also be painted, and there is a new leak in the roof that should be repaired.

The wood shed at the school has never been painted and would be the better of a coat of arsenite paint but it may be too late to have it done this fall.

your obedient servant

Indian Agent.

The Secretary

Ottawa, September 15, 1926.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the Sheshogwaning R. C. Day School, I beg to say that you may have the necessary kalsomining done, also the window frames and sash painted and the leak in the roof repaired. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred.

Next spring you might submit an estimate of the cost of having the woodshed painted, and this matter will receive consideration at that time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. F. Priddle, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

I herewith enclose report of R.C.Bay school Shehagwaning for month of September.

I beg to advise that Miss LaVictoire asks that a radio be installed in the school as it is a social gathering place for the Indians on Saturday nights and Sundays and our teacher has a idea that she can purchase a radio that has been used very cheaply.

My own idea is that a cheap radio is of very little use and although a radio would be very useful in the school and would help keep the Indians out of trouble as they generally get into when left to their own devices I would not recommend buying a radio unless the Department saw fit to purchase some reliable machine.

your obedient servant

Indian Agent

The Secretary
Dept.of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.
Ottawa, September 24, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School to be supplied with a radio. In this connection I have to say that the Department does not furnish this type of equipment to Indian schools, and it is therefore regretted that we will be unable to comply with the teacher's request. It is thought that, if the teacher desires a radio, she could obtain the funds for the purpose by entertainments or by contributions from the Indians, who would receive benefit from same.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

Ottawa, July 7, 1930.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School, states that the roof is leaking in several places, also that the furnace needs to be overhauled. I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange during the present summer holidays to have the roof of the school building repaired and placed in good condition. You should also arrange to have the furnace overhauled. If any new parts are required, they should be installed and the furnace placed in good condition and ready for use next Fall. It is expected you will see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in carrying out these repairs and, when completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of any material and for the labour. It is noted that only minor repairs will be required to place both the roof and furnace in good condition.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

MEMO FOR FILE:

On the 2nd instant I visited the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School and I found quite an interesting little community centre. This is a fairly good building, with a flashed roof, which is now giving trouble and concerning which the Agent will report. They have many outbuildings, nice flower and vegetable gardens and good equipment throughout. This school is a social centre for the elder people of the reserve during the evenings. Miss LaVicteire, of the Mariane Order, and one assistant comprise the staff and they are proving a very good civilizing influence. They need a few desks and an extra bed, and, as these were surplus at the closed C. of E. School, I asked the Agent to send the equipment over. He is also to send a washstand to Little Current, to be picked up by Agent Lewis for the Kaboni School. I intend to authorize the Agent to purchase four stools for community purposes.

Sir:

With reference to official letter No 12-3-5 June 23rd last regarding the roof at Sheshgwaning R.G.School.

In this connection Mr Baxter the local plumber and tinsmith here states that soldering the roof would be of no use and states that as this roof has been on the school for about 18 years in his opinion a new roof over the old one would be the most satisfactory job and he estimates that a new roof laid on and painted would cost around $175.00 and I believe also that a new roof would be really the best way possible to make a real good job that would last a long time. In the first place the roof only leaked at the gutters but this spring Miss LaVicoire claimed that there was several places leaking slightly at different points in the roof.

As it is the wish of the Department to keep expenditures as low as possible this year I would think that a suitable paint might be purchased and applied twice to this roof with a tar or cement in the gutters that would last a few years and not cost very much.

Your obedient servant

Indian Affairs Agent

Ottawa, July 23rd, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the repairs required to the roof of the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School building.

In reply I have to say that the Department has no funds to provide the cost of installing a new roof. It is considered that it would be satisfactory to have two coats of a suitable paint applied to the present roof and the gutters given a coat of tar or cement, and you may arrange to have this done. You should arrange for the purchase of a suitable type of paint and for the labour in having same applied. The roof should be given two coats and the gutters covered with tar or cement. While a satisfactory job should be completed, all costs for material and labour should be kept as low as possible. This work should be carried out before the school reopens after the present summer holidays. Only Indians should be employed.

After the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of all materials and for the labour.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I herewith enclose requisition for material for R.C. School Sheshgwaning.

The teacher has asked for material for supplying hot lunches to the scholars and in addition to this she is starting a sewing class and asks for material suitable for girls dresses and boys shirts and it is her intention to have the class make the garments and then give the dresses to the scholars and the shirts to the boy scholars. I think that a sewing class would be much more valuable to the Indian girls than a crocheting class and the children can certainly use the dresses and shirts to wear in going to school.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, October 17, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Sheshegwaning R. C. Indian Day School for supplies for a hot lunch to the pupils, sewing materials and supplies for the use of the school.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the list to receive consideration, of the following: 1 gal. floor oil, 1 alarm clock (Big Ben type), 6 bars Comfort soap, 2 wash basins (white granite), 1 pail for chemical closet, 1 nine quart tin pail, 2 brooms, 12 generators for Coleman lamp, 2 shut-off valves, 10 gals. coal oil, 5 gals. gasoline, 2 mantles for Aladdin lamps and 1 cleaner.

Regarding the supplies for the pupils' midday meal, I have to say that our funds are limited this year, and it will only be possible to supply materials for the serving of a hot drink at midday. You may, therefore, purchase a small supply of cocoa and sugar. If the Indian children are unable to bring milk, you may purchase a small quantity of condensed milk. I may say that the purpose of the hot drink is to augment the lunch brought by the pupils from their homes.

Regarding the sewing material asked for, you may purchase 12 spools black thread, No. 60, and 20 yards flannelette. You should consult the teacher regarding the colours of the flannel-ette required.

After you have made the above authorized purchases, you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

I may add that the half dozen tooth brushes, text-books, etc., will be forwarded to the teacher from here.

Your obedient servant,

E. F. Priddle, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gore Bay, Ont.

Secretary.

your obedient servant

Sir:

I herewith enclose report of R.C.School Sheshegwaning and beg to advise that the roof of the school is again leaking very badly. I counted eight different places where the water comes through and some of them are real bad spots. Two years ago we painted the roof to make it stop leaking and it served very well up till now but it is a metal roof and it will either have to be soldered or else a new roof. It is doubtful if it can be soldered properly to stop the leaks.

The pump is not working either and the Indians do not seem able to repair it properly. I would recommend that I be allowed to take Mr Baxter up from here and let him look over the roof and make an estimate of a new roof or see if the old one can be repaired and also repair the pump at same time. This would probably cost about $5 and would be very satisfactory as Mr Baxter is a plumber and tinsmith.

The trees at the back of the school are very dense and shade the garden a great deal. I would recommend that these be trimmed out and the lower limbs trimmed off. There should also be a new ladder made that will reach to the roof of the school as the old ladder is broken and rotten and there is no way of getting on the roof in case of fire etc.

I would estimate the cost of underbrushing and building of a ladder at $10 and a competent man could be employed to make a good job of the work. As I am discontinuing all relief on the reserve for next month except to aged and infirm I could employ a man that needs the work.

I also beg to advise that there should be about 10 cords more furnace wood supplied to school as there is going to be a shortage of dry wood for next winter as more wood was burned than was figured on leaving a shortage. I would recommend that someone be given the job of cutting 10 cords and leaving it in the wood to dry till next winter when it could be drawn to the school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Sir;-

I herewith enclose monthly report of Sheshegwaning R. C. for month of June 1936.

I beg to advise that the flag pole at this school is very high and whenever the rope breaks that carries the flag up to the top it is necessary to borrow a pair of climbing irons and get some of the Indians to climb the pole and put a new rope through the pulley at the top.

It would be much simpler if pole was cut off and then irons put through the top piece and fastened to the piece left in the ground so that all that would be necessary would be to release the bolts and take the pole down. The pole would still be plenty long enough and as it is now it is hard to get anyone to risk climbing same. The necessary change could be made at a cost not exceeding $4 or $5 and I would recommend that this be done.

The Secretary
Dept.of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont
